title: Do Not Prevent The Fertility Of The Mind

  physical_appearance: This installation depicts a wall
 decorated with women\u0027s sanitary napkins
 and bordered by fluorescent lights. In the center
 there is a framed photograph of a woman. She is dressed in a red top
 wearing a headpiece with a red cross
 and holding wire tools in both her hands. In front of the wall
 there is a stool. On the stool
 there is a red vial filled with red liquid placed on a plastic sheet.

  subject_terms_1: political art government policy avant-garde reproduction (biological event)

  subject_terms_2: Art Political aspects Women\u0027s rights Government policy Birth control Pro-life movement Installations (Art)

  subject_terms_3: Installation art

  sgcool_label_text: Central to Arahmaiani’s work is the theme of the position of women
 particularly in Indonesian society. Do Not Prevent The Fertility of the Mind draws on the artist’s personal experience of being arrested in her student years for her performance art
 and conflates ideas of artistic creativity with female fertility
 commenting on how both these impulses are curtailed by watchful authorities. Making reference to the Suharto government’s birth control policies of the 1990s
 which the artist views as a “coloniz(ation) by the state even to the innermost part of (women’s) bodies”
 Do Not Prevent The Fertility of the Mind expresses the narrow confines within which avant-garde artists had to work
 even as it confronts the viewer with the (often taboo) bodily realities of a woman’s reproductive capabilities – and
 by extension
 her artistic creativity.

metadata.physical_appearance: This installation depicts a wall, decorated with women's sanitary napkins, and bordered by fluorescent lights. In the center, there is a framed photograph of a woman. She is dressed in a red top, wearing a headpiece with a red cross, and holding wire tools in both her hands. In front of the wall, there is a stool. On the stool, there is a red vial filled with red liquid placed on a plastic sheet.
metadata.subject_terms_1: political art government policy avant-garde reproduction (biological event)
metadata.subject_terms_2: Art Political aspects Women's rights Government policy Birth control Pro-life movement Installations (Art)
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Central to Arahmaiani’s work is the theme of the position of women, particularly in Indonesian society. Do Not Prevent The Fertility of the Mind draws on the artist’s personal experience of being arrested in her student years for her performance art, and conflates ideas of artistic creativity with female fertility, commenting on how both these impulses are curtailed by watchful authorities. Making reference to the Suharto government’s birth control policies of the 1990s, which the artist views as a “coloniz(ation) by the state even to the innermost part of (women’s) bodies”, Do Not Prevent The Fertility of the Mind expresses the narrow confines within which avant-garde artists had to work, even as it confronts the viewer with the (often taboo) bodily realities of a woman’s reproductive capabilities – and, by extension, her artistic creativity.
